According to Rule 55.1 of the PCT and the relevant provisions in the UPCA, for a request for unitary effect, an applicant must provide a translation of the specification into one of the official languages of the European Patent Office (EPO) if it was filed in a non-official language. In this case, Mr Linguist filed his application in Dutch but uses English as the language of proceedings. Since he is requesting unitary effect on 10 October 2024, he must provide a translation of the specification into an official language of any of the states to which the unitary effect extends.

- **Option A**: This option suggests providing a translation in Dutch, but since Dutch is not one of the EPO's official languages and Mr Linguist is requesting unitary effect in multiple states, this would be incorrect.
  
- **Option B**: This statement is correct as per Rule 55.1(b)(i) which requires a translation into an EPO official language when an application has been filed in a non-official language. The list of EPO's official languages includes Dutch and English among others, so Mr Linguist can provide the translation in any of these.
  
- **Option C**: This statement is incorrect because it refers to 24 states that have signed the UPCA (Unified Patent Court Agreement), which is broader than just the states for which a unitary effect request may be made. The requirement specifically pertains to the official languages of the EPO, not all states under the UPCA.
  
- **Option D**: This option suggests providing a translation in Spanish, but as it is not an official language of the EPO, this would also be incorrect.

Therefore, Mr Linguist must provide a translation of the specification into an official language of any of the 18 states to which the unitary effect extends (Option B).
